Public’s aid sought in 1990 Gardner Museum art heist

Federal officials investigating the art theft plan to launch a public awareness campaign similar to the one that led to the arrest of James ‘‘Whitey’’ Bulger. (Globe)

Brain sample damage affects research

A freezer malfunction at Harvard-affiliated McLean Hospital has severely damaged one-third of the world’s largest collection of autism brain samples. (Boston Globe)

pictures

Food truck festival comes to Boston

More than 5,000 people got a chance to sample fare from food trucks from around the region Sunday at the Boston Food Truck Festival held at UMass Boston in Dorchester.
  • pictures Boston's top food trucks | Brookline food trucks
  • discuss Your favorite food truck? | More June food events

Computers may show drugs' side effects

Scientists at a Cambridge biotech laboratory have developed a computer to test drugs for adverse side effects before being given in clinical trials. (Boston Globe)
  • 5/31: RXi cleared to start scar-reducing drug trial
  • 3/29: Antipsychotic drugs for seniors have hidden peril
  • 3/9: Side effects for cholesterol-lowering statins

Study: Gulf of Maine’s food chain at risk

Researchers found that record rains in recent years and the resulting sediment in the Gulf of Maine threaten the plants that are the basis of the marine food chain. (Globe)
  • 5/23: Mass. fishermen: No sure way to rise above woes
  • 3/29: Gulf of Maine ocean temperatures above normal

Maine dam removal aims
to rescue fish species

A multimillion-dollar project will allow endangered and dwindling species to return to their historic spawning grounds along Maine’s Penobscot River.

Europe’s crisis hits firms in Mass.

Bay State companies that depend on Europe for much of their business are reporting slowing overseas sales as the debt crisis there deepens.
Opinion | Adrian Walker

In search of transparency

Adrian Mims alleges he was passed over as headmaster of Brookline High because he is black, a complaint that has roiled the town, a liberal bastion in the state.

For scientists, fish expert is a catch

Ellis London has been the go-to local expert on marine organisms for more than 40 years.

Another casino player in New England

The Oxford Casino opened on Route 26 in Western Maine early this month, two years after voters narrowly approved it in a statewide referendum.
Opinion | JULIETTE KAYYEM

Suicide the biggest foe for US troops

While the Pentagon has made serious efforts to address suicide, the growing number of these cases suggests that the message isn’t taking hold.

Holocaust survivors deal with PTSD

Researchers are finding that the passage of time does not always diminish traumatic symptoms — and old age can actually aggravate them.
